name: DSE Mathematics - Problem Solving
subject: Math
instructions: This rubric is used to assess mathematical problem-solving questions in HKDSE Mathematics. Evaluate across three dimensions: Mathematical Understanding, Problem-Solving Process, and Communication.

levels.descriptor: Demonstrates complete understanding of mathematical concepts. Correctly identifies all relevant formulas and theorems. Shows deep insight into the problem structure.
Demonstrates good understanding with minor gaps. Identifies most relevant mathematical concepts correctly.
Demonstrates adequate understanding. Some concepts may be applied incorrectly or incompletely.
Limited understanding demonstrated. Major misconceptions in applying mathematical concepts.
Little or no understanding demonstrated. Fails to identify relevant mathematical concepts.
Solution is complete and logically structured. All steps are clearly shown with correct calculations. Efficient problem-solving strategy employed.
Solution is mostly complete with clear logical flow. Minor computational errors that do not significantly affect the answer.
Solution shows reasonable approach but may be incomplete. Some steps missing or computational errors present.
Partial solution with significant errors or missing steps. Problem-solving approach is unclear.
Little progress toward solution. Major errors in approach or calculations.
Mathematical notation and terminology used correctly and precisely. Working is well-organized and easy to follow. Units and significant figures handled correctly.
Good use of mathematical notation with minor errors. Working is organized. Mostly correct handling of units.
Adequate use of notation. Some disorganization in working. Occasional errors in units or significant figures.
Limited use of mathematical notation. Working is difficult to follow.
Poor or no mathematical notation. Working is disorganized or absent.

commonErrors: Forgetting to write units in final answer
Forgetting to check solutions in the original equation
Misreading the question or missing constraints
Confusing similar formulas (e.g., area vs perimeter)
Not considering all cases in conditional problems
